Casey Foubert }} '''The Shins''' is an American [[indie rock]] band formed in [[Albuquerque, New Mexico]], in 1996. The band is the project of singer-songwriter [[James Mercer (musician)|James Mercer]], who has served as the band's sole constant member throughout numerous line-up changes. The band's current line-up consists of Mercer, alongside Yuuki Matthews (bass, keyboards), [[Mark Watrous]] (guitar, keyboards, lap steel), Patti King (keyboards), and [[Jon Sortland]] (drums).{{cite web|url=http://pitchfork.com/news/70701-the-shins-announce-tour/|title=The Shins Announce Tour|last=Sodomsky|first=Sam|website=[[Pitchfork (website)|Pitchfork]]|date=January 5, 2017|access-date=January 5, 2017}} They are based in [[Portland, Oregon]]. The band was formed by Mercer as a side project to [[Flake Music]], who were active from 1992 to 1999. Flake Music released two 7-inch singles and a full-length album, ''[[When You Land Here It's Time to Return]]'', on Omnibus Records and were touring with [[Modest Mouse]] when the Shins became signed to [[Sub Pop Records]]. The Shins' first two records, ''[[Oh, Inverted World]]'' (2001) and ''[[Chutes Too Narrow]]'' (2003), performed well commercially and received critical acclaim. The single "[[New Slang]]" brought the band to mainstream attention when it was featured in the 2004 film ''[[Garden State (film)|Garden State]]''. Consequently, the band's third album, ''[[Wincing the Night Away]]'' (2007), was a major success for the group, peaking at number two on the [[Billboard 200|''Billboard'' 200]] and earning a [[Grammy Award]] nomination. Following this, the Shins signed to [[Columbia Records]] and Mercer parted ways with the entire original lineup, deeming it "an aesthetic decision". Following a near five-year hiatus, ''[[Port of Morrow (album)|Port of Morrow]]'', the band's fourth studio album, was released in 2012. Their fifth album, ''[[Heartworms (album)|Heartworms]]'', was released in March 2017. ==History== ===Early years (1996–2000)=== [[File:Downtown Albuquerque Route 66.JPG|thumb|The Shins were formed in [[Albuquerque]], [[New Mexico]].]] The Shins was formed in 1996 by James Mercer, a member of the band Flake Music in [[Albuquerque]], [[New Mexico]]. Flake Music (formerly known simply as Flake) consisted of members guitarist/vocalist James Mercer, drummer Jesse Sandoval, keyboardist Martin Crandall, and bassist Neal Langford. The group began in 1992 and released a string of singles and an album, ''[[When You Land Here, It's Time to Return]]'', which was well received. The band toured with [[Modest Mouse]] and [[Califone]]. Mercer formed the Shins for a change of pace and enlisted Sandoval on drums. When asked what it was that began his interest in music, Mercer said "... it got me out of my shell and gave me a social life."{{cite web|url=http://www.spin.com/2012/02/spin-interview-james-mercer/ |title=The SPIN Interview: The Shins' James Mercer |publisher=SPIN |date=February 22, 2012 |access-date=March 10, 2017}} They began performing as a duo alongside [[Cibo Matto]] and [[the American Analog Set]]. Mercer became the band's primary songwriter, and consequently, "the group developed a more focused, crafted sound than Flake Music's charming, if somewhat rambling, collaborative style." His focus on percussive guitar playing still led friends to compare his demos as too similar to Flake, and he focused on taking the music in a different direction. Unlike Flake, Mercer was the band's sole lyricist, and songs were built from his initial structure. The group added [[Scared of Chaka]]'s Dave Hernandez and Ron Skrasek to complete their lineup, but the two musicians left before the end of the decade to pursue their work with Scared of Chaka. By 1999, Flake Music disbanded and Neal Langford joined the Shins. The Shins issued their first release — the 7" single ''[[Nature Bears a Vacuum]]'' — in 1998 via Omnibus Records. Following the completion of their debut single release, "When I Goose-Step", the Shins embarked on a tour with Modest Mouse. Mercer became a "hermit" crafting what would become the group's debut album, and became depressed with his life in Albuquerque.{{cite web|author=Colin Delaney |url=http://www.tntdownunder.com/article/2446199116.html |title=Interview with - The Shins |website=TNT Magazine |date=December 13, 2007 |archive-date=October 1, 2009 |access-date=July 19, 2014 |url-status=dead |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20091001133553/http://www.tntdownunder.com/article/2446199116.html }} Friends of the band, including Zeke Howard from Love As Laughter and [[Isaac Brock (musician)|Isaac Brock]] from [[Modest Mouse]] sent record labels [[compact cassette|cassette]] demos of the band's songs.{{cite news|author=Michael Henningsen |url=http://www.alibi.com/alibi/2001-06-21/feature_section.html |title=Oh, Inverted World: The Shins Prepare to Turn the Music World Upside Down |newspaper=[[Weekly Alibi]] |date=June 21, 2001 |archive-date=April 19, 2003 |access-date=July 19, 2014 |url-status=dead |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20030419055751/http://www.alibi.com/alibi/2001-06-21/feature_section.html }} Mercer sent a demo to [[Sub Pop Records]] in [[Seattle, Washington]], and label co-founder [[Jonathan Poneman]] caught a concert in [[San Francisco]] while the band was on tour with Modest Mouse. He offered the band a one-off single deal, and the Shins' second single, "[[New Slang]]", was included as part of their Single-of-the-Month series, issuing a 7" single to fan club members in February 2001.{{cite news|author=Paul Maldonado Jr. |url=http://www.abqtrib.com/archives/diversions01/062901_diversions_shins.shtml |title=Shins hope to create a little history with release of CD |newspaper=[[The Albuquerque Tribune]] |date=2001 |archive-date=March 1, 2003 |access-date=July 19, 2014 |url-status=dead |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20030301144748/http://www.abqtrib.com/archives/diversions01/062901_diversions_shins.shtml }} Positive press for "New Slang" made the group's debut album one of the most anticipated [[indie rock]] albums of 2001, and Sub Pop signed the band in full. "Before you knew it, my whole life was upside down: I got signed, I quit my job, I moved out of town, the big relationship I'd had for five years ended. All of a sudden my whole life was up in smoke," recalled Mercer.{{cite magazine|url=https://www.spin.com/2012/02/spin-interview-james-mercer/|title=The ''SPIN'' Interview: James Mercer|author= Kelly Clarke |date=February 22, 2012|magazine=[[Spin (magazine)|Spin]]|access-date=July 19, 2014}} ===Debut and growing popularity (2001–03)=== The band's debut LP, ''[[Oh, Inverted World]]'' (2001), was released in June 2001, with a [[compact disc]] version following the next month. Much of the album was recorded prior to the Sub Pop deal in Mercer's basement. The album received critical acclaim and solidified the band as one of [[indie rock]]'s definitive artists, while also placing Albuquerque on the musical map with ''Oh, Inverted World's'' "gloriously skewed pop and [how it is] dripping with yearning, whimsy and brittle innocence."Simpson, Dave. "Friday Review: REVIEW MUSIC: POP CD RELEASES: The Shins Oh, Inverted World: 4/5 Stars." The Guardian [London] May 24, 2002: n. pag. Print. The album helped re-establish Sub Pop Records as a dominant force in the independent community; the label had been without a marquee artist for many of the prior years.{{cite magazine|title=The Shins Biography: ''Rolling Stone'' |magazine=[[Rolling Stone]]|url=https://www.rollingstone.com/music/artists/the-shins/biography|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110212172622/http://www.rollingstone.com/music/artists/the-shins/biography|url-status=dead|archive-date=February 12, 2011|access-date=July 20, 2014}} The group spent the rest of the year touring with acts such as Preston School of Industry and Red House Painters.{{cite web |author=Heather Phares|title=The Shins - All Music Guide |website=[[Allmusic]] |url=http://www.allmusic.com/artist/the-shins-mn0000419102/biography|access-date=July 20, 2014}} "[[New Slang]]" proved to be a "stealth hit", helping ''Oh, Inverted World'' move over 100,000 copies within two years, considered remarkable for an independent label; Sub Pop had hoped the record would sell 10,000 copies. Mercer was positive in licensing the song to a variety of media, confirming to ''The New York Times'' that he received more money from touring and licensing than record sales.{{cite news|author=Kelefa Sannah |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2003/10/22/arts/rock-celebrities-stealth-without-trying-too-hard-shins-have-become-indie.html|title=Rock Celebrities by Stealth; Without Trying Too Hard, the Shins Have Become an Indie Phenomenon|newspaper=[[The New York Times]]|date=October 22, 2003|access-date=July 19, 2014}} The song was featured in a [[McDonald's]] advert that aired during the [[2002 Winter Olympics]],{{cite news|author= Matt LeMay |url=http://community.seattletimes.nwsource.com/archive/?date=20020221&slug=shins21|title=The Shins get a bite from McDonald's|newspaper=[[The Seattle Times]]|date=February 21, 2002|access-date=July 19, 2014}} which led to criticism from several corners, among those independent music fans and the band's own hometown [[alt weekly]].Klein, Bethany (2009). ''As Heard on TV: Popular Music in Advertising''. [[Farnham]]: [[Ashgate Publishing]], pp. 127-131. First edition, 2009.{{cite magazine|author=Zac Crain|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=crQoYila-dAC&q=new+slang+interview+shins&pg=PA133|title=The Shins - ''Chutes Too Narrow''|magazine=[[Spin (magazine)|Spin]]|date=December 2003|volume=19|issue=12|page=133|access-date=September 7, 2012}} The [[royalties]] Mercer earned from the commercial allowed him to purchase a home and relocate to [[Portland, Oregon|Portland]], [[Oregon]], where the group built a basement studio and recorded their second album, ''[[Chutes Too Narrow]]'' (2003).{{cite news|author= Lash Bower |url=http://alibi.com/music/18598/James-Mercers-Inverted-World.html|title=James Mercer's Inverted World|volume=16|issue=14|newspaper=[[Weekly Alibi]]|date=April 5, 2007|access-date=July 19, 2014}} During this period, the group replaced Langford on bass with Dave Hernandez (from Scared of Chaka). Having cut ties with a bad relationship and a bad job, Mercer felt his songwriting reflected a broader perspective as a result.{{cite journal | url=https://www.rollingstone.com/music/news/the-shins-make-basement-tapes-20030805| title=The Shins Make Basement Tapes| journal=[[Rolling Stone (magazine)|Rolling Stone]]| date=August 21, 2003 | access-date=July 14, 2013 | author=Eliscu, Jenny| issue =929| page =58| publisher =[[Jann Wenner|Wenner Media]] [[Limited liability company|LLC]]| location =[[New York City]] | issn =0035-791X}} Although recording in the basement was less than pleasant, the band found it "cheaper than a real studio". The home was broken into at one point, and thieves stole the master tapes for ''Oh, Inverted World''. The album was released in October 2003 to critical acclaim, appearing on numerous music critics' and publications' end-of-year albums lists.{{cite journal | title=50 Best Albums of 2003| journal=[[Rolling Stone (magazine)|Rolling Stone]]| date=December 25, 2003 | issue =938/939| page =110| publisher =[[Jann Wenner|Wenner Media]] [[Limited liability company|LLC]]| location =[[New York City]] | issn =0035-791X}}{{Cite news| title=Staff Lists: Top 50 Albums of 2003|url=http://pitchfork.com/features/staff-lists/5925-top-50-albums-of-2003/5/|publisher=[[Pitchfork Media]]|access-date=July 14, 2013| date=December 31, 2003}} It also became their first album to chart, peaking at number 86 on the [[Billboard 200|''Billboard'' 200]]. ===Mainstream success (2004–07)=== {{Listen |filename = The Shins - New Slang.ogg |title = "New Slang" |description = "[[New Slang]]" was featured in the 2004 film ''[[Garden State (film)|Garden State]]'' and brought the band mainstream success. }} "New Slang" was repurposed when it was prominently featured in the film ''[[Garden State (film)|Garden State]]'' (2004). In a scene from the film, Sam (portrayed by [[Natalie Portman]]) tells Andrew Largeman (played by director [[Zach Braff]]) that the song "will change your life." The song "changed everything" for the group, causing their first two albums to sell more than twice what they had sold prior to the film's debut. "Almost overnight, the Shins became indie-rock icons," wrote Robert Levine of ''[[Spin (magazine)|Spin]]''.{{cite magazine|author=Robert Levine|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=G-FewpAsvB0C&q=new+slang+interview+shins&pg=PA70|title=The Shins' Big Adventure|magazine=[[Spin (magazine)|Spin]]|date=February 2007|volume=23|issue=4|pages=68–72|access-date=September 7, 2012}} The band extended their tour in support of the song and its popularity.{{cite magazine|author= Will Levith |url=http://www.americansongwriter.com/2007/03/the-shins-pressed-in-a-book/|title=THE SHINS: When You Are Wincing |magazine=[[American Songwriter]]|date=March 1, 2007|access-date=July 19, 2014}} "We saw a change in our audience. By the time we were done touring for ''[[Chutes Too Narrow]]'', there was this new interest," said Mercer. "We toured again almost as the soundtrack to that movie, and colleges were all of a sudden interested in us playing on their campuses. We wanted to consummate the new relationship by touring and having a relationship with them. I mean, it just kept growing!"{{cite web|author= Aleeza Khan |url=http://www.ionmagazine.ca/music/profiles/james-mercer-the-shins|title=The Shins|website=Ion Magazine|date=February 8, 2012|access-date=July 19, 2014}} This additional exposure helped ''Oh, Inverted World'' move 500,000 units in the United States. Fans of the group had mixed reactions at their newfound success; some regarded their unknown nature as an integral part of their appeal. The band also appeared in [[Gilmore Girls (season 4)|season four]], episode 17 of [[Gilmore Girls]] while Rory and Paris are on spring break in Florida. Mercer began writing the band's third record in late 2005, employing ideas and riff fragments collected over the band's various tours. Suffering from insomnia, he would often wake up in the middle of the night and piece together songs in his home studio until dawn. For their third album, the group for the first time turned to an outside producer: [[Joe Chiccarelli]], who produced [[Frank Zappa]]. Inspired primarily by a painful breakup and the group's newfound success, the album was initially set to be released in the summer of 2006. It was later pushed back to fall, and finally released in January 2007. ''[[Wincing the Night Away]]'' represented a major jump for the Shins in terms of commercial success: the album peaked at number two (in comparison to its predecessors' peak of number 86), setting a record for Sub Pop. It moved over 100,000 copies in its opening week, and was nominated for a [[Grammy Award]] for Best Alternative Album. Following the success of the album, The Shins left their longtime label, [[Sub Pop]], for Mercer's own label, Aural Apothecary.{{Cite news| last=Phillips| first=Amy| title=Shins' James Mercer Spills About Lineup Changes, New Album, Other Projects|url=http://pitchfork.com/news/35257-shins-james-mercer-spills-about-lineup-changes-new-album-other-projects/|publisher=[[Pitchfork Media]]|access-date=July 14, 2013| date=May 6, 2009}} ===Hiatus and one-man band (2008–13)=== [[File:The Shins House of Blues Dallas.jpg|thumb|The Shins performing in 2012.]] Having worked on The Shins for nearly a decade, Mercer felt exhausted and ready to quit the band. "Mainly I was tired of being right in the middle and everything sort of revolving around me, including the friendship dynamics-slash-bandmate dynamics and the creative aspect," Mercer explained in 2012. Noting that the band had never been bigger, some aspects of the limelight made him uncomfortable. Mercer was approached by Brian Burton ([[Danger Mouse (musician)|Danger Mouse]]) around this same period regarding a possible collaboration on a new project, which became [[Broken Bells]].{{cite magazine| last=McDonnell| first=Tim| title=Catching Up With the Shins' James Mercer |url=https://www.motherjones.com/mixed-media/2012/02/james-mercer-shins-port-of-morrow-interview|magazine=[[Mother Jones (magazine)|Mother Jones]]|access-date=July 14, 2013| date=March 12, 2012}} Enjoying the fresh approach with Broken Bells in regard to meeting new musicians, Mercer desired to continue that feeling. Mercer parted ways with longtime bandmates Dave Hernandez, Marty Crandall and Jesse Sandoval, terming it "an aesthetic decision".{{Cite news| last=Montgomery| first=James| title=Shins Will Return After James Mercer Is Done With Broken Bells, He Says|url=http://www.mtv.com/news/articles/1630710/shins-will-return-after-james-mercer-done-with-broken-bells.jhtml|publisher=[[MTV News]]|access-date=July 14, 2013| date=January 28, 2010}} Sandoval instead told ''The Portland Mercury'' he was "unequivocally fired" from the group by Mercer.{{Cite news| last=Breihan| first=Tom| title=Former Shins Drummer Jesse Sandoval: "I Got Fired"|url=http://pitchfork.com/news/36145-former-shins-drummer-jesse-sandoval-i-got-fired/|publisher=[[Pitchfork Media]]|access-date=July 14, 2013| date=August 6, 2009}} Mercer would later relate that his decision was "tremendously difficult", but instead wished to view it as a new phase. Working with Burton on Broken Bells helped Mercer overcome fears of collaboration, which in turn influenced the rotating "cast of characters" that grouped together around him to record ''[[Port of Morrow (album)|Port of Morrow]]'', which became the Shins' fourth album upon its March 2012 release. Mercer returned to The Shins as the only original member. "I always loved these auteurs who presented themselves as bands," Mercer later explained, referencing [[Neutral Milk Hotel]] and [[Lilys]] as examples, which led to him feeling as though he could pursue something similar, allowing the concept of The Shins to carry on.{{cite magazine| last=Clarke| first=Kelly| title=The ''SPIN'' Interview: James Mercer|url=https://www.spin.com/2012/02/spin-interview-james-mercer/|magazine=[[Spin (magazine)|Spin]]|access-date=July 14, 2013| date=February 22, 2012}} Producer Greg Kurstin had a particular influence on ''Port of Morrow'', encouraging Mercer to experiment in the studio.{{cite news| author=Hyden, Steven| title=Interview: James Mercer of The Shins|url=http://www.avclub.com/articles/james-mercer-of-the-shins,71391/|newspaper=[[The A.V. Club]]|access-date=July 14, 2013| date=March 17, 2012}}{{Cite news| author=Sisario, Ben| title=The Second Act Of an Indie Success Story|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2012/03/18/arts/music/james-mercer-and-the-shins-return-with-port-of-morrow.html?pagewanted=all|journal=[[The New York Times]]|access-date=July 14, 2013| date=March 16, 2012}} Mercer began touring with an all new backing band, including fellow songwriters [[Jessica Dobson]] and [[Richard Swift (singer-songwriter)|Richard Swift]], Modest Mouse drummer Joe Plummer, and Yuuki Matthews from the Crystal Skulls. ''Port of Morrow'' debuted at number three on US charts,{{cite magazine | url={{BillboardURLbyName | artist=The Shins | chart=Billboard 200}} | title=The Shins – Chart History: Billboard 200 | publisher=[[Prometheus Global Media]] | magazine=[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]] | access-date=March 1, 2013}} and lead single "[[Simple Song (The Shins song)|Simple Song]]" represented the band's best chart performance, peaking within the top 10 on the [[Alternative Songs]] chart.{{cite magazine | url={{BillboardURLbyName | artist=The Shins | chart=Alternative Songs}} | title=The Shins – Chart History: Alternative Songs | publisher=[[Prometheus Global Media]] | magazine=[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]] | access-date=March 1, 2013}} ===Recent events (2014–present)=== [[File:Shins 2017.jpg|thumb|The Shins performing in 2017.]] In 2014, The Shins recorded and released a new song, "So Now What", for the soundtrack of ''[[Wish I Was Here]]'' (directed by Zach Braff of ''Garden State''). Mercer noted to ''Billboard'' that he was immensely proud of how the track came out: "I think it's one of the best things I've ever done."{{cite magazine| title=The Shins' James Mercer: Zach Braff Soundtrack Song 'One Of The Best Things I've Ever Done'|url=http://www.billboard.com/articles/news/6128813/the-shins-zach-braff-soundtrack-so-now-what-interview|magazine=Billboard|access-date=June 24, 2014| date=July 20, 2014}} That November, a reissue of Flake Music's first album, ''[[When You Land Here It's Time to Return]]'', was released. In 2016, the group recorded a cover of [[the Beatles]]' "[[The Word (song)|The Word]]" for the [[Netflix]] show ''[[Beat Bugs]]''.{{cite web|url=http://pitchfork.com/news/67155-the-shins-cover-the-beatles-the-word-for-netflixs-beat-bugs-listen/|title=The Shins Cover the Beatles' "The Word" for Netflix's "Beat Bugs": Listen|website = Pitchfork|date=July 28, 2016|access-date=January 5, 2017}} During this time, Mercer was at work on the band's fifth album, which he felt was closer in sound to the Shins' earlier work than ''Port of Morrow'': "I made a concerted effort on certain songs to fit the palette, to use the palette that I've used historically for the band."{{cite web|title=The Shins Say New Album Is Done, Coming "Early Next Year"|url=http://pitchfork.com/news/67549-the-shins-say-new-album-is-done-coming-early-next-year/|date=August 14, 2016|website = Pitchfork|access-date=August 14, 2016}} The group announced their new album, ''[[Heartworms (album)|Heartworms]]'', in January; it was released on March 10, 2017.{{cite web|url=http://pitchfork.com/news/70701-the-shins-announce-tour/|title=The Shins Announce Tour|author= Sam Sodomsky |website = Pitchfork|date=January 5, 2017|access-date=January 5, 2017}} In January 2018, they released ''[[The Worm's Heart]],'' an album which reimagined their previous album ''Heartworms''.{{Cite news|url=https://consequenceofsound.net/2018/01/the-shins-unveil-new-album-the-worms-heart-stream/|title=The Shins unveil new album, The Worm's Heart: Stream|date=January 19, 2018|work=Consequence of Sound|access-date=January 22, 2018|language=en-US}} Former band member Swift died on July 3, 2018.{{cite web |title=Richard Swift Dead at 41 {{!}} Pitchfork |url=https://pitchfork.com/news/richard-swift-dead-at-41/ |website=pitchfork.com |date=July 3, 2018 |access-date=July 3, 2018 |language=en}} He was admitted to the hospital in June for hepatitis.{{Cite news|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/entertainment-arts-44699301|title=The Black Keys' Richard Swift dead at 41|date=July 3, 2018|work=BBC News|access-date=July 4, 2018|language=en-GB}} On September 24, 2020, the band released a new single titled "The Great Divide".{{Cite web|last=Bloom|first=Madison|date=September 24, 2020|title=The Shins Share Video for New Song "The Great Divide"|url=https://pitchfork.com/news/the-shins-share-video-for-new-song-the-great-divide-watch/|access-date=2020-09-24|website=Pitchfork|language=en-us}} In April 2021, a 20th anniversary reissue of ''Oh, Inverted World'' was announced for release on June 11, 2021. The reissue was remastered by [[Bob Ludwig]], with Mercer serving as an assistant.{{cite web |last1=Moreland |first1=Quinn |title=The Shins Announce 20th Anniversary Reissue of Oh, Inverted World |url=https://pitchfork.com/news/the-shins-announce-20th-anniversary-reissue-of-oh-inverted-world/ |website=Pitchfork |date=April 13, 2021 |publisher=Pitchfork Media |access-date=13 April 2021}} A "21st birthday" tour of North America was announced in May 2022, where The Shins will play ''Oh Inverted World'' in its entirety.{{cite web |last1=Minsker |first1=Evan |title=The Shins Announce Oh, Inverted World 21st Birthday Tour |url=https://pitchfork.com/news/the-shins-announce-oh-inverted-world-21st-birthday-tour/ |website=Pitchfork |publisher=Pitchfork Media |access-date=13 May 2022}} ==Musical style and influences== Mercer described the Shins as a "[[pop music|pop]] project" from the beginning. The group were inspired by any and all music that they discovered. "Everything we listen to [...] makes its way in somehow, but we've been inspired by a bunch of bands who basically just keep reinventing the same thing," said Mercer. The group received comparisons to the "pop revivalists" at the Elephant 6 Recording Collective early in their career,{{clarify|date=August 2020}} such as [[The Apples in Stereo]],{{clarify|date=August 2020}} whilst Mercer's vivid, often surrealist lyrics and infectious melodies drew comparisons to the songwriting style of [[Robert Pollard]] from [[Guided by Voices]].
